citation: Carter, Jimmy. 1977. “Presidential Speech on Soviet Relations.” Washington, D.C., March 1977.
annotation: President Carter’s brief address frames U.S.–Soviet relations in terms of democratic deliberation and strategic arms control.  Conceptually, the speech shifts national‐security discourse from bipolar military antagonism toward cooperative arms-limitation, while stressing the domestic legitimacy that comes from public and congressional debate.  Although short, the text introduces a compact vocabulary of Cold-War strategy, democratic oversight, and balance-of-power reasoning.

vocabulary.definition: The overall safety and defense of the United States, framed primarily in relation to the Soviet Union.
vocabulary.source_context: “Our national security was often defined… in terms of military competition with the Soviet Union.”

vocabulary.definition: The strategic course of action the United States pursues toward other nations, historically centered on U.S.–Soviet relations.
vocabulary.source_context: “For decades, our foreign policy revolved around antagonism between two coalitions…”

vocabulary.definition: A hostile or oppositional relationship between rival coalitions.
vocabulary.source_context: “…revolved around antagonism between two coalitions…”

vocabulary.definition: A bloc of states aligned under a leading power (U.S. or Soviet Union).
vocabulary.source_context: “…between two coalitions, one headed by the United States and the other headed by the Soviet Union.”

vocabulary.definition: Rival accumulation and deployment of armed forces and weapons systems.
vocabulary.source_context: “…defined almost exclusively in terms of military competition with the Soviet Union.”

vocabulary.definition: Bilateral negotiations aimed at capping and reducing U.S. and Soviet strategic weapons.
vocabulary.source_context: “In the talks on strategic arms limitations, the SALT talks…”

vocabulary.definition: The act of placing ceilings on long-range nuclear weapons and delivery systems.
vocabulary.source_context: “…strategic arms limitations…”

vocabulary.definition: A wide-ranging plan covering multiple elements of arms control.
vocabulary.source_context: “…we advanced a comprehensive proposal for genuine reductions…”

vocabulary.definition: Authentic, verifiable decreases in the number or capability of strategic weapons.
vocabulary.source_context: “…a comprehensive proposal for genuine reductions and limitations…”

vocabulary.definition: A parity of military capability that neither advantages nor disadvantages either superpower.
vocabulary.source_context: “…that would maintain balanced strategic strength.”

vocabulary.definition: The presidential process of selecting courses of action on complex issues.
vocabulary.source_context: “I feel more secure as President making decisions if I know…”

vocabulary.definition: Open discussion among citizens and institutions regarding policy choices.
vocabulary.source_context: “…have been understood and debated by Congress and the American people.”

vocabulary.definition: The requirement that elected officials justify and expose decisions to legislative and popular scrutiny.
vocabulary.source_context: Implicit in the President’s wish that Congress and the American people debate security issues.

vocabulary.definition: Multifaceted policy issues requiring deliberation and expertise.
vocabulary.source_context: “…the most difficult, complex questions that face me…”

vocabulary.definition: The U.S. legislative branch as a deliberative actor in foreign-policy oversight.
vocabulary.source_context: “…debated by Congress and the American people.”

vocabulary.definition: The domestic public constituency whose understanding legitimates foreign policy.
vocabulary.source_context: “…debated by Congress and the American people.”

vocabulary.definition: Cognitive grasp of the issues by stakeholders prior to decision implementation.
vocabulary.source_context: “…have been understood and debated…”

vocabulary.definition: A world order dominated by two superpower blocs (U.S. and USSR).
vocabulary.source_context: Implied by reference to “two coalitions… headed by the United States… [and] Soviet Union.”

vocabulary.definition: Competition for military and political advantage between great powers.
vocabulary.source_context: “…military competition with the Soviet Union.”

vocabulary.definition: Negotiated limitations on the development, deployment or use of weapons.
vocabulary.source_context: Entire discussion of SALT talks and proposals for reductions.

vocabulary.definition: The quantitative decrease of existing weapons systems.
vocabulary.source_context: “…genuine reductions and limitations…”

vocabulary.definition: Equilibrium of capabilities that prevents dominance by any single actor.
vocabulary.source_context: “…maintain balanced strategic strength.”

vocabulary.definition: Aggregate capability of strategic (usually nuclear) forces.
vocabulary.source_context: “…balanced strategic strength.”

vocabulary.definition: Joint assessment and discussion by multiple stakeholders before action.
vocabulary.source_context: “…debated by Congress and the American people.”

vocabulary.definition: Perceived appropriateness and acceptance of governmental decisions.
vocabulary.source_context: Implied rationale for seeking public and congressional debate.

vocabulary.definition: Decision processes that actively involve citizens and representatives.
vocabulary.source_context: President’s emphasis on debate beyond the executive branch.

vocabulary.definition: The prevention of hostile action by fear of retaliatory capability; underlies strategic strength.
vocabulary.source_context: Implicit in references to balanced strategic strength and arms limitation.

vocabulary.definition: A rivalry in which one side’s gain is perceived as the other’s loss.
vocabulary.source_context: “…national security… defined… in terms of military competition…”

vocabulary.definition: Open disclosure of strategic intentions and proposals.
vocabulary.source_context: The President’s willingness to advance and publicize a comprehensive proposal.

vocabulary.definition: A condition in which neither superpower has incentive to launch a first strike, fostered by balanced forces and arms limits.
vocabulary.source_context: Goal implied by “balanced strategic strength” and limitation talks.
